clinical_study.brief_title: VRH Pain Reduction During Burn Wound Care and Physical Therapy
clinical_study.official_title: Testing Interactions to Adjunctive Pain Control Techniques

lead_sponsor.agency: National Institute of General Medical Sciences (NIGMS)

clinical_study.source: National Institute of General Medical Sciences (NIGMS)

brief_summary.textblock: Using Virtual Reality Hypnosis to relief pain and anxiety for burn patients.

detailed_description.textblock: The purpose of the study is to examine whether there is more effective relief of pain and anxiety during wound care procedures in burn-injured patients that are treated with Virtual Reality Hypnosis with post-hypnotic suggestion.

primary_outcome.measure: we use GRS, VAS, McGill,and nurse GRS to measure the pain.

arm_group.description: Arm one uses Virtual Reality Hypnosis post hypnotic suggestions to reduce pain durng wound care procedures.
Arm two uses Virtual Reality distraction that is administered at times other than during burn care procedure to control for both for attention and high technology.
Arm three use Audio administered Hypnosis without the visual technology.

intervention.intervention_name: using VR hypnosis/distraction and audio hypnosis
intervention.description: a between subject comparison using VR hypnosis and VR distraction and audio hypnosis for pain control

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age greater than or equal to 7 years
- Able to complete subjective evaluations of pain
- English-speaking
- Not demonstrating delirium, psychosis, or any form of Organic Brain Disorder
- Able to communicate orally
Exclusion Criteria:
- Age less than 7 years
- Incapable of indicating subjective evaluation of pain
- Non-English-speaking
- Demonstrating delirium, psychosis, or Organic Brain Disorder
- Unable to communicate verbally
- Significant developmental disability
- Extreme susceptibility to motion sickness

facility.name: University of Washington; Harborview Medical Center

reference.citation: Patterson DR, Tininenko JR, Schmidt AE, Sharar SR. Virtual reality hypnosis: a case report. Int J Clin Exp Hypn. 2004 Jan;52(1):27-38.
